description.value: Outcome CVD (coronary death, myocardial infarction, coronary insufficiency, angina, ischemic stroke, hemorrhagic stroke, transient ischemic attack, peripheral artery disease, heart failure)

citation.value: Cardiovascular disease (10-year risk) [Internet].: Framingham Heart Study; cited 2017]. Cardiovascular Disease (10-year risk). Available from: https://www.framinghamheartstudy.org/risk-functions/cardiovascular-disease/10-year-risk.php.

title.value: General cardiovascular risk profile for use in primary care: the Framingham Heart Study

description.value: BACKGROUND: Separate multivariable risk algorithms are commonly used to assess risk of specific atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease (CVD) events, ie, coronary heart disease, cerebrovascular disease, peripheral vascular disease, and heart failure. The present report presents a single multivariable risk function that predicts risk of developing all CVD and of its constituents.

citation.value: D'Agostino RB S, Vasan RS, Pencina MJ, Wolf PA, Cobain M, Massaro JM, et al. General cardiovascular risk profile for use in primary care: the Framingham Heart Study. Circulation. 2008 February 12;117(6):743-53

title.value: NICE guidance. Chest pain of recent onset: assessment and diagnosis of recent onset chest pain or discomfort of suspected cardiac origin

citation.value: Skinner JS, Smeeth L, Kendall JM, Adams PC, Timmis A, Chest Pain Guideline Development Group. NICE guidance. Chest pain of recent onset: assessment and diagnosis of recent onset chest pain or discomfort of suspected cardiac origin. Heart. 2010 June 01;96(12):974-8.

description.value: Adult patients
Adult with stable CP being considered for cardiology consultation (excluding unstable symptoms and ACS)
Provider in Primary Care Clinic
noninvasive diagnostic orders (stress testing)

name.value: Professor, Cardiovascular Medicine, University of Utah School of Medicine; Staff Cardiologist, Salt Lake City VA Medical Center (VAMC)
Assistant Professor, Cardiovascular Medicine, University of Utah; School of Medicine Staff Cardiologist, Electrophysiology, Salt Lake City VAMC
Professor of Medicine, Wayne State University; Section Chief, Cardiology, John Dingell VAMC

description.value: This order set is not applicable for use with patients who are unstable based on clinician judgement. Examples of unstable patients include, but are not limited to, patients with chest pain pattern suggestive of ACS (e.g., those with new onset resting CP, CP with minimal exertion, new unstable angina pattern, ST-segment elevation, nonâ€“ST-segment elevation myocardial infarction on ECG, or suspected aortic dissection), and patients with any of the following symptoms or findings. Consider transferring unstable patients to the nearest emergency department immediately

textEquivalent.value: Ongoing resting chest pain for > 20 minutes with ST elevation or depression on ECG

prompt.value: Ongoing resting chest pain for > 20 minutes with ST elevation or depression on ECG

textEquivalent.value: Onset of new resting chest pain episodes within the past week

prompt.value: Onset of new resting chest pain episodes within the past week

textEquivalent.value: New onset, recurrent chest pain with minimal exertion over the past 2 months.

prompt.value: New onset, recurrent chest pain with minimal exertion over the past 2 months.

textEquivalent.value: Previously stable exertional angina now occurring with minimal activity over the past 2 months.

prompt.value: Previously stable exertional angina now occurring with minimal activity over the past 2 months.

description.value: Consider other consult modalities which might be available (e.g., e-consult or other rapidly iterative consult method. A simple consult is included here as the overarching clinical intent.

textEquivalent.value: Referral to cardiology to evaluate chest pain (routine)

displayText.value: progressive angina symptoms in a stable patient with known CAD (if the patient is unstable based upon clinical or test results, direct physician-to-physician communication is required)

description.value: Consider ordering prior to the cardiology consultation. Resting 12-lead electrocardiogram is required if it has not been obtained within the past two months.

textEquivalent.value: Order sentence: resting 12-lead electrocardiogram to evaluate chest pain (routine)
Order sentence: x-ray chest to evaluate chest pain (routine)

description.value: Consider ordering prior to the cardiology consultation.

prompt.value: Is Coronary CTA (cCTA) availability at the facility

textEquivalent.value: Coronary CTA angiogram (cCTA) chest to evaluate chest pain (routine)

elm:value.display: coronary CTA chest to evaluate chest pain

description.value: Consider for patients with suspected pericarditis, myocarditis, hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, or pulmonary hypertension.

prompt.value: Is the patient suspected with pericarditis, myocarditis, hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, or pulmonary hypertension.

textEquivalent.value: Resting echocardiogram to evaluate chest pain (routine)

elm:value.display: Resting echocardiogram to evaluate chest pain

title.value: Consider the following tests to be completed prior to the cardiology consultation.

description.value: For stable patients, these orders may assist in cardiac risk stratification. A link to the ACC/AHA clinical practice guideline for stress testing should be made available to ordering providers:

title.value: Assess for contraindications to stress testing such as: Acute Congestive Heart Failure (CHF), acute MI or unstable angina, severe aortic stenosis, unstable rhythm, aortic aneurysm/dissection, endocarditis, acute pericarditis, acute pulmonary embolus/infarction, acute systemic illness/infection, severe hypertension, inability to cooperate, inability to exercise (<5 METs), left bundle branch block (LBBB), etc.

description.value: Consider for patients with no known or prior coronary artery disease, low probability for coronary artery disease, ability to exercise, normal electrocardiogram, and heart rate > 60 beats per minute.

Consider for patients with no known or prior coronary artery disease, low to intermediate probability for coronary artery disease, ability to exercise, and no evidence of significant regional wall motion abnormalities or conduction abnormalities (IVCD/bundle branch block or pacing) of 12-lead electrocardiogram.

title.value: Dobutamine Stress Testing with Myocardial Perfusion Imaging (MPI)

description.value: Consider for patients with no known or prior coronary artery disease, intermediate probability for coronary artery disease, inability to exercise, and normal electrocardiogram.
Consider for patients with known or prior CAD, ability to exercise, and normal ST-T.

Consider for patients with known or prior CAD and abnormal electrocardiogram/PPM. This subsection should also be made available to the provider for patients with known or prior CAD, abnormal electrocardiogram, and history of prior myocardial infarction or regional wall motion abnormalities.

textEquivalent.value: Adenosine stress testing myocardial perfusion imaging (routine)
Dipyridamole stress testing myocardial perfusion imaging (routine)

title.value: Dobutamine Stress Testing with Echocardiography or MPI

description.value: Consider for patients with known or prior CAD, inability to exercise, normal electrocardiogram, and no prior myocardial infarction. Only one should be selected.

textEquivalent.value: Dobutamine stress testing myocardial perfusion imaging (routine)

description.value: Consider for patients without known coronary artery disease, low or intermediate probability for coronary artery disease, especially in presence of a history of prior inconclusive or discrepant diagnostic testing, recurrent symptoms or significant family history of CAD/multiple risk factors in young patients. Additional postprocessing (CT-FFR) or CTA stress perfusion may be ordered where available.
Consider the following medications for stable patients to be initiated prior to the cardiology consultation.

textEquivalent.value: metoprolol tartrate 25 mg tablet oral twice daily (routine)
metoprolol tartrate 50 mg tablet oral twice daily (routine)
nitroglycerin 0.4 mg tablet sub-lingual every 5 minutes as needed for chest pain; maximum 3 tablets (routine)

elm:value.display: every 5 minutes as needed for chest pain

textEquivalent.value: aspirin 81 mg enteric coated tablet oral daily (routine)
